WRITING.TEXT: Many libraries are actually trying to phase out late fees. Where I work we have constantly talked about decreasing the fines on books since the overall "profit" of late fees on materials means close to nothing. What we've done is introduce erroneously named initiatives like a "rewards club," where checking out 100 items removes the possibility of late fees on your account for the rest of the year. We have movies and tv shows to check out as well, so people will just come in and take 10 movies every few days and soon not have to worry about late fees again. We encourage it because we want circulation stats and the patrons love it because they don't want to pay fines. Go find a suggestions box or forum for your library and bring the idea up. They might take you up on the idea if enough support and interest is shown.

Yes, good idea. I just read The Little Book of Hygge, which goes deep into the Danish obsession for warm candle lighting, cozy places, and blankets, and how that has helped them become the planet's veritable titans of happiness. So I've already been envisioning the scene you have conjured up, my man. Thanks for the instrumental suggestions, that's a field I have a pressing need for exposure to!

Which do you recommend? The copy I got so long ago is the MacAndrew translation, so I'm going to stick with that for this reading. I'm most interested in picking up the Pevear and Volokhonsky translation to compare.

WRITING.TITLE: Beginning The Brothers Karamazov, anyone have any advice for me?
WRITING.TEXT:
I decided to finally start the book I've had on my reading list since I was a sophomore in high school. My history teacher gave a soapbox speech about it to us, concluding that if we wanted to know ourselves we should read The Brothers Karamazov. Years went by and I ended up taking 3 years of Russian language and culture classes in college, but never found the time for Dostoevsky. More years went by and now that I'm done with my masters, pulled out the paperback copy I bought close to 10 years ago and am ready to begin. As added incentive, my girlfriend has agreed to begin her own treacherous, long put-off book, House of Leaves, if I get through this. I'm a librarian now, so a man's gotta do what he's gotta do to get his fellow dudes to read.
I thought I'd submit a thread asking my book friends for any tips, strategies, or general advice they might have for me before I get started. I've been exposed to Russian lit and its language before, so I totally understand that nickname conventions and the huge cast of characters are hard to grasp at first, but I think I'll be okay in that regard. I suppose what I'm asking is also more for you to share your thoughts and supply some insights, or point to accompanying material/literature that can enhance the read for me. Really anything to motivate me even more to embark on this journey is appreciated. I want book hype, I want sources that provide literary context, I want someone to say, "Hey, take it from me, you should draft up a character web to help you navigate through the story," or, "Eat some borscht and embrace your inner east Slavic."
What it comes down to is I'm excited and want everyone else to be excited. Not for me, but because there are great books out there, prolific books that can mean so much to someone despite having never read the work before. Books that carry so much clout with them that just opening up the cover can fills us with an unparalleled giddy anticipation for the journey about to unfold. I'm raving, perhaps emotionally off-kilter. Whatever. I hope everyone can enjoy a nice book tonight, and thanks in advance for anything you end up sharing.

Yeah, that'll work. I was griping more about trying to secure alliances at the start date, when I have no money for extra mercs. And with this -50 malus to diplo relations that AI get now, Byzantium runs are miserable.

Ooohh, that'd be cool to get Bulgarians to spawn. Although how do you mean free clay? In that if their demands are met, they'll become an independent nation, thus probably allowing me to declare war on them immediately before they can gather allies? I'm a little foggy on how support rebels work, and how that translates to "free clay".
I'm guaranteeing Candar at the moment, as I went a little crazy in Poland and up through Crimea. I have Caffa and the two provinces neighboring either side of it, and those are definitely in fabrication distance for when the time comes.
Iberia is unfortunately all under Castile's solid rule. I've seen Naples break away so many times this patch, too. Of course they don't when I finally manage to get a footing now.
I'm gonna need a lot more than just those three provinces, haha. I plan on integrating Serbia later, so it shouldn't be an issue.
Ohh, good thinking about guaranteeing. Thanks!

I've had a lot of difficult allying anyone in these runs. I'm guessing have a diplo rep. adviser is necessary, since the Mamluks are never in range of being allied. But yeah, Hungary will eventually be betrayed once I get my foothold. From what everyone has been saying, I'll focus my attention of wiping out the Ottomans first.
I'm thinking Poland must have lost its war to the Teutonic Order and they forced them to break their alliance with Lithuania. Either way, they're fighting each other now. \_()_/

Just looking for advice. Was hoping to go for Basileus and don't feel like restarting 100 more times if this one goes south. So how do I succeed from here?
I've got a truce timer with the Ottomans until '91 because I accidentally took a ton of land off Venice without realizing it and started a massive coalition war. That was bad. Poland obviously chose to go with a local lord and is fighting Lithuania now. Austria got the inheritance. Everything else looks pretty normal for an early game besides my PU with Serbia and Wallachian Vassal. My plan is to go in through Italy with a claim on the Papal State, but I'd like to finish off the Ottomans first, I think. What should my plan of attack be from here?

WRITING.TITLE: Alright, lads, how do I avoid mucking up this Byzantium run?

WRITING.TEXT: I'm more interested in how the Ottomans haven't cleansed your people after 90 years of play.

Yeah, I don't mean to diminish your efforts haha. Even when things go completely your way, it takes a lot of experience to convert those positive events into absolute boons for your run. Knowing how to manage all of what comes your way for good or for bad, especially when you're playing within the HRE, is a good feeling.
Not for that war, no.

Wait, so all you have to do to win the HRE is have everything go your way?! WHAT HAVE I BEEN DOING ALL THIS TIME.
Nevertheless I'm happy for your successes, friend.

Dude, I'm with you on the Azael thing. I don't want to just sit here and bash the guy on personal preference, as I do genuinely think he's a good analyst in post game talks and such. But in game his casting always seems like he's casting to prove something. He's very negative on player performances and quick to call out how bad of a decision something is, but in my opinion color casting should be more about breaking down the gameplay, setting up why the play occurred, and then speaking about the ramifications of it.
Azael seems far too reactive in game, mimicking play-by-play casters too much, trying to follow the action and show off his knowledge at the same time. This restricts the depth of his analysis and what comes out is just really rudimentary observations like "ARE YOU KIDDING ME?! WITH THAT ACE THEY CAN JUST GO MID AND END THE GAME" or "WHAT A TURN AROUND! THIS MEANS THEY CAN GO STRAIGHT TO BARON!" And then he'll follow-up with comments that say something like "See, that was really good for them because it was good for them." I think he gets caught up in the moment, and that ends up sacrificing a lot of insight. He has that full-of-himself vibe going on, and that's not necessarily a bad thing. I just don't think he's proven that he deserves that tone, based on the knowledge he's so rarely expressed.

Consider donating them to your local library if you really don't like them, or don't see yourself wanting to keep them. Many libraries are really struggling these days, (for example, the state of Illinois refuses to pass a state budget, and libraries have been truly suffering for the past couple of years), so if those books are in great, circulation condition, you might be able to contribute to their collection. And if not, most libraries have a book sale section for anyone to purchase donations. Those funds go to the Friends of the Library clubs or directly back to the library itself.

In my PLC game, a hundred or so years in, a message popped up asking if I wanted to go to war for a PU over a relatively weak France. I hit escape by accident and cancelled out of the notification and they went uncontested over to my rival Austria. It was a sad day.
Yeah, every once in a while. Especially when the Netherlands fails to stick. Sometimes Gelre, too. That region gets pretty crazy sometimes, where nations swing back and forth in power.

Right? I don't want to sit here and just bash the book relentlessly or anything, like I said I think Rothfuss is a really talented author. But he just needs to reign it in a bit. He's got the potential the blow the fantasy genre out of the water, but I can't fathom how it's going to be worth the time invested at this point.

I'm not sure what you mean. I never said it would, but the main conceit of the book is that Kvothe is retelling his story over the course of three days to the scribe. Rothfuss is using Kvothe to stretch this whole unreliable narrator thing to its bounds. At this point, if he doesn't end with Kvothe, or provide some conclusion for him, what was the point of the 1500+ pages of the first two books relating entirely to Kvothe?
Don't get me wrong, I like the books, and think Rothfuss is a fantastic story-teller. But they were some of the most frustrating reads I've ever committed to.

In regard to The Name of the Wind, it has never felt "worth it" to me. The structure of the plot is scattered and all over the place, and it's really just Rothfuss telling one tale after another of Kvothe's crazy, wacky adventures. There's this pretension of an underlying plot, and there's a lot that he does well--better than any fantasy writer out there today--but for how long book one and book two are, I expected much more progress to be made in the narrative. Instead, Rothfuss meanders for 1500 pages. I have no idea how he expects to wrap this up as a trilogy, and I don't want to set myself up for a pessimistic viewpoint, but I can't see it ending in a satisfying way.

I wanted to do the same thing, but instead I subscribed to Goodreads and set a year goal of 32ish books. This creates a tangible checkoff list for me that helps. I have a real hard time both motivating myself to read, and then remaining focused on it when I do open up the cover. I go through spurts of reading now, reading one book while listening to another on my drive to work one week, then nothing for the next. My unspoken goal is to get 3-4 books completed a month, which is like 1 book a week, but more forgiving. Some weeks I'm not in a good mental state, so setting monthly or yearly goals makes me feel better about what could be a hard to maintain rigid weekly schedule.
Dude, The Remains of the Day is so good. Stephens is one of the most finely realized characters in literature.
Lazy/bad at the game.

I suppose you're right about the Czech Republic, it would just be a change of government, really. It's wishful thinking, haha.
Though, I'm not sure I agree that just because something is ahistorical, it shouldn't be in the game. Scandinavia exists, for example. Westphalia and Hanover are formable nations, too. While Czechoslovakia never lasted as a country, it's still as much a goal to aspire to such as the like of Sweden becoming Scandinavia, or Hesse forming Westphalia. What's really the point of tag-switching to these nations other than something else to do with your nation?
But I do like the idea of Austria-Hungary. Really, anything that could give the Czechs something else to do after the Hussite narrative goes away.
Liege survives on my good graces.
Oh, tons. Tons of dead Africans.

I've never gotten the Burgundian Inheritance to fire for me, mainly because I'm morally opposed to falling in line with the Habsburg/Papal State pressure early on. You get a lot of diplomatic malus for going the Jiri z Podebrad route. But getting a Habsburg on the throne early and sticking with him can open up a whole big, fun can of diplo-worms.

Prussia, Germany, Poland. Just takes some effort and culture swapping, but I get what you mean. It'd be nice to be able to have the option to form Czechoslovakia or the Czech Republic prematurely just for kicks. I get that they were under Habsburg rule for all of EU4's time period, but if you can form Germany or restore the Roman Empire before 1821, you can at least allow Bohemia to tag switch to Czechoslovakia and maybe add a cultural union with the Slovakia region or something.

I looked at my statistics post game and was informed that I had no disasters triggered throughout my playthrough. I think I kind of just take their stability for granted sometimes. I usually end up sparking some disaster somewhere along the way playing someone else. (Looking at you Count's Feud...)
I think Bohemia has one of the most interesting early game starts for HRE gameplay.
There's this really cool map mode feature that they added into the game called Terrain. Check it out if you want to see the natural geography of the land!
Seeing that picture makes my heart flutter with joy.
I kept them alive to send a message.
Honestly I didn't care about trading at this point. I just clicked a few buttons and left it how it was. I had been making a hefty profit continuously for the final 200 years, so whatevs.
Yeah, Denmark really messed up.
Yeah, I already got that one.

Nothing too special, I was just proud of my latest Bohemia game where I decided to dismantle the HRE. Pretty much concerned myself with knocking out everyone exclusively in the HRE until 1700, and then I got a chance to contest a PU with France. I would've like to have been able to integrate them, but alas.
It ended up being too late to remove the Ottomans, so I just nibbled off Spain, London, Tunis, and Italy for the remaining years. It's the most I've expanded in a game before, and started getting really boring towards the mid 1700s. Had no idea what achievement I could've gone for that I didn't already have, and ended up getting Market Control.

WRITING.TITLE: They didn't want to elect me HRE so I made my own.

WRITING.TEXT: Fever Dream! Really gripping and uniquely written. I rarely feel the level of ominous dread to the extent that I did during reading that.
That was my first foray into Mitchell. A fantastic book. Reading Thousand Autumns presently, glad to hear more praise!

Bakewell is great at presenting a clear depiction of the existentialist movement in that book. Stick with it! I just finished it a week or two ago and has spurred some real interest in reading the works of the philosophers she discussed.
You know, I loved Atlantis Found when I was in high school. I thought Cussler was going to be one of my favorite authors. But damn me if he doesn't just regurgitate adventure plots every year.

I had heard a lot of praise for Locke Lamora, but I was similarly apathetic about a lot of it. I listened to it on my rides home from work, and it was enjoyable enough, but it doesn't seem to have had a lasting impact. The characters are all wise-cracking, witty delinquents and Lynch's dialogue was enjoyable, but by the end it just all felt like one of those 1st in a trilogy vapid summer blockbusters. I'm in the same boat whether or not I'll continue it at some point, but I was hoping more time would've been spent on lore and world-building then on finely crafted back-and-forth dialogue.

The Mariner's Revenge Song is just about the greatest modern sea chanty you'll ever hear. A rollicking 9 minute tale of retribution on the high seas.
Otherwise, the rest of the Picaresque album uses traditional diction and themes of the genre, with the first two songs in the album personally the most catchy/relevant to your interests. The Crane Wife and The King is Dead are also two classic Decemberist album that I'd check out if you end up liking Picaresque.

Everything, haha. I find myself reading and rereading passages, trying to figure out what exactly he's trying to get at. What's the purpose of this specific point of the plot, or why is he spending time meandering around this subject for pages on end. I go into every novel knowing that he's writing some kind of satire, but there's no way for the reader to join in on the whole joke if you take it all at surface value. His works are incredibly rewarding, but they are a labor.

An entertaining, playful modern retelling of the gothic picaresque/fairy tale that I read last year was Patrick DeWitt's "Undermajordomo Minor." Thomas Pynchon's books often have a lot of characters with qualities resembling those in picaresque novels, employing peculiar names and idiosyncrasies, but he's a difficult author sometimes, and you have to work for an understanding of his stuff. His "Crying of Lot 49," is a nice short introduction to his style, and "Inherent Vice" is a comical riff on detective novels that was recently made into a movie. Not a novel, but whenever I hear the word Picaresque, the Decemberists album of the same name comes to mind, and is amazing. Lyrical picaresque characters and antiquated plotlines woven into song.

part 1: https://www.reddit.com/r/eu4/comments/63z3gr/couldnt_sleep_so_i_spent_3_hours_writing_a/
Due to adequate demand, I've returned with part two of my long-winded period drama, "Bohemia AAR". This one is a doozy, 36 images in length. My thoughts were to create an album for each ruler as I played them, but I'm not sure if that'll be able to be kept up. Mr. Jiri z Podebrad lasted for quite a while, but his successors might not. People might not like to read too many image descriptions either, so should I continue with this recreational project, I'll do my best with the pacing.
For the time being, I hope you enjoy reading my chronicle of the early history of Bohemia. I had a lot of fun creating the narrative for Jiri, so hopefully that comes across in the writing.

WRITING.TITLE: An Insomniac's Bohemian AAR Part TWO, The Reign of King Jiri, aka Electric Boogaloo, otherwise known as Battle Tendency, more commonly referred to as The Hussites Strike Back.

WRITING.TEXT:
You could be right, it's been awhile since I took classes on the subject. From what I recall, Chiang spent a lot of his time hunting down the Red Army sympathizers (exhibit A: The Long March), It was the Red Army guerrilla warfare tactics against the Japanese and resource sharing with small, devastated villages of peasants near the Northern Manchuria occupied regions that garnered them a lot of support. Obviously, they couldn't fight effectively either with the Nationalist Army of China hunting them down.
I don't mean to romanticize the Red Army, nor discredit the Nationalist army fully. I think Chiang didn't get criticized enough, especially by Americans due to us "siding" with him throughout the war. While he was in a precarious position, I think he was far too obsessed with wiping out the Red Army. This is all my own personal belief, though, and I can understand sentiment either way. It's just what I learned about the whole situation developed a certain bias against him and his tactics during the war. Thanks for bringing up the other side of the argument!

The Chinese casualties were Chinese civilians and disarmed soldiers. Most did not have military training, so fighting was not an option for them. Nanking was their home. A cease-fire to evacuate the city was proposed, but Chiang Kai-Shek refused to surrender the city. It's important to recognize state of the nation of China was in disarray, that while Chiang technically ruled the country, he proved completely inept at fighting the Japanese invasion. Instead, he spent much of his resources eliminating the Red Army.
Sorry I don't have any numbers for the Japanese invading army, but I figured that if the core of your question was why the Chinese didn't fight back, that is better answered by examining what was going on internally in China at this time. A lot of great history books have been written about this topic if you're looking to research, one that comes to mind is Edgar Snow's account of the Red Army in the Red Star Over China, which concerns itself with the political situation in China before the Japanese invasion.
*edit: The film City of Life and Death by Lu Chuan was a great visualization of the Massacre itself, too. Touches on the disarmed soldiers, women, children, and International Ambassadors within the city during the occupation, and what they went through.

The Stormlight Archives are the only Sanderson books I've read, and I've greatly enjoyed them. While there are only two publishing, the third is set to come out later this year I believe. The characters are really well written, and the pacing of his world building was really satisfying. I say this latter point because I'm incredibly frustrated with Rothfuss's Kingkiller Chronicles, as I feel like for a large portion of the books, so many facets of society are left unexplored. Sanderson introduces such a diverse array of characters and different perspectives that everything about his world comes together seamlessly in an engrossing way.
I don't think you need to read any other of Sanderson's books first, like others have suggested, unless you want to appreciate the apparent shift in his writing skills. Some characters, however, have connections to his great literary universe, so perhaps reading other books will tune you into those cross-overs. All in all, though, a fantastic stand-alone series.

I read that work in college for a class I took on World War II era China. As an American whose country always condemns communism as some abject terror, it was extremely elucidating to see how the Red Army functioned. Snow produced a much needed exposure of Mao Zedong, Zhao Enlai, and other forerunners of the Communist China. Good on you for committing to this one!

*Edit, part 1: https://www.reddit.com/r/eu4/comments/63z3gr/couldnt_sleep_so_i_spent_3_hours_writing_a/
Due to adequate demand, I've returned with part two of my long-winded period drama, "Bohemia AAR". This one is a doozy, 36 images in length. My thoughts were to create an album for each ruler as I played them, but I'm not sure if that'll be able to be kept up. Mr. Jiri z Podebrad lasted for quite a while, but his successors might not. People might not like to read to many image descriptions, either, so should I continue with this recreational project, I'll do my best with the pacing.
For the time being, I hope you enjoy reading my chronicle of the early history of Bohemia. I had a lot of fun creating the narrative for Jiri, so hopefully that comes across in the writing.

So I found myself unable to sleep tonight, so I gathered some pictures from my recent Bohemia game (trying out the new free patch features), and attempted to actually role play a little bit. I put a little bit a time into it, reading up on wikipedia to throw in some historical grounding, and generally devising a sub-par storyline to go along with the events of my playthrough. I kind of wanted to take it slow with this run, and focus on goals from ruler to ruler. Figured if I ended up chronicling it, at least that'd be a good way to catalog each part.
This being said, you might intuit that the first part here is fairly short since Bohemia begins in interregnum and then Jiri z Podebrad pops up and overthrows your first king. Or at least, that's how I always play them because I feel strongly about that kind of thing (Habsburgs be damned).
Anyway, thanks for reading whoever does. I'm just a simple man who likes to look at maps, so I apologize for any mistakes I made. It's also 3am. Goodnight, reddit.

WRITING.TITLE: Couldn't sleep, so I spent 3 hours writing a Bohemia AAR. Let me know if it's worth continuing!

WRITING.TEXT: This might not be as strange as it is something I just don't understand. I was playing Austria and annexed a Romagna and Ancona from the Papal State. This generated some Urbino Separatist rebels. I didn't secure military access over to stop them from rising up, so they occupied both provinces and then crossed the sea and took Istria from me, too. I decided to just accept their demands, which were "All provinces owned becomes Urbino," or something like that. When I accepted, the separatists seemingly become my troops, and the occupied statuses all disappeared. I figure maybe it had something to do with Urbino still having been a vassal under the Papal State, but I have no clue.

I did my Luck of the Irish run with Thomond, and found it slightly easier than Desmond. While morale and manpower theoretically can help against someone like England, but early on it won't make much difference. You need good allies and numbers to push back England. Thomond's money making ideas gives you the funds to actually create the army that Desmond dreams of early on--when you'll need it. If you have late game ambitions, certainly Desmond will have the edge, so I can see the allure. You can argue that they have objectively the better ideas, as they align more with how most people play this game (expand and expand and be the best army you can be). However, you can also argue that Thomond has ideas better suited for more comfortable gameplay, emphasizing a stronger economy and colonizing. I'd say choose which style you want to play, then choose accordingly.

I saw that on NPR's book concierge last year and was interested. I checked it out at my library, but had a stockpile of end of the year best of books that I never got around to reading it. Good to hear more praise about it to keep it on my radar!

R5: Just an album of images relating to my Lucky Lucca run. Was kind of surprised to see this listed as a "Very Hard" achievement on the wiki, as it seemed to me to be more about patience rather than anything else. As long as you can set up an early hold in Northern Italy, it's primarily just colonizing and chilling with strong allies for the rest of the game.

WRITING.TITLE: Lucky Lucca pre 1700

WRITING.TEXT: Yeah, first it was Savoy. Then I was able to secure France. Then France got angry at me for something and I jumped into the soft arms and heroic chins of Austria. I believe early game, though, Lucca usually is friendly toward the Papal State, whereas Florence is pretty much hard-coded as a rival to them always.
Thanks! With a little patience in conquering provinces and securing friends in high places, you too can achieve mediocre success as little Lucca!
Girl, don't you worry about Lucca. http://imgur.com/a/L2XHo

Yeah, I guess that has to be it. I guess it's just the combination of Austria having weak heirs/negative prestige all early game long while Hesse (a two province nation in the middle of a volatile HRE) survived aggression and still maintained enough clout for 100 years to dominate the votes every election. Brandenburg and Bohemia were doing quite well this run, and usually I see them vote for themselves at some point. The amount of Protestant electors that continued voting for Hesse after 1500 (Again, Brandenburg and Bohemia converted, yet still overwhelmingly voted Hesse).
I just found it peculiar how Hesse continually defied the odds, and maintained such a strong hold on the throne. Thanks for the enlightenment, I didn't know about the IA stored influence thing!

I want to preserve this name placement forever. You can put a straight line under that tag and it would STILL be perfect. They're straight shooters, those Palatines. Angles and curves be damned, we're GOING STRAIGHT THROUGH NUREMBURG'S BORDERS.
T H E P A L A T I N A T E
**T H E P A L A T I N A T E** ######T H E P A L A T I N A T E

WRITING.TITLE: T H E P A L A T I N A T E (Tag Porn)

WRITING.TEXT:
R5: I'm also kind of posing a question to everyone here. I didn't think it was super strange that Austria didn't get votes in the first election, but then Hesse won again. And again. And Again. I have no idea how, but for a solid century, every elector was locked into voting for Hesse. Here's the screenshot I took marking the first time Austria took back emperorship. (And still...most electors switched back to voting exclusively for the Hessians)
http://imgur.com/a/Ostvf
You can also barely see that Hesse's IA was at 71 in the title picture, and managed to keep boosting it up for their century of power. But no one would vote for any reforms, so the HRE remained impotent.

WRITING.TITLE: Alternate Fact: Von Habsburgs lost. I'll tell you this, they lost, alright? Hesse has the best emperors. The people agree. Trust me.

WRITING.TEXT:
Hah, I suppose it's just a passive kind of game. Honestly, if Austria doesn't inherit the Lowlands, I rarely see them expanding much into the HRE on their own. More often I see Brandenburg or Bohemia get strong on the east side, Cologne or Munster or some random, unstable duchy that had no right being big miraculously accumulate a chunk of land in the west, and Austria in the south. Usually the religious war sparks some excitement in relationships throughout, but I guess you didn't get lucky there.
The one time I played through Poland to the end I did feel a little bit unstoppable. Once Russia is out of the picture, and if the Ottomans stagnate, you can just go wherever you want making the right alliances. Maybe try colonizing Canada and begin a colonial war to spice things up!

You're saying that Russia, nor the Ottomans, nor France, nor Spain, nor Great Britain, nor Austria, nor any alliance between any of these typical great powers is going to be your enemy? Usually alliance blocks form between rivals around this time, so I would expect you to find some opposition team-up on you. Otherwise you could be doing well enough on your own, Poland can get pretty strong.
I'm not sure what your plan on playing is, but games can be fairly boring if you're not pushing AE to its bounds, backstabbing allies, and remain complacent in your position. Not saying any of this is what you're doing, it's just I'm not really sure what the state of your game really is, or what you expect it should be. If you don't interact with France or the HRE, not a whole lot is guaranteed to change.

Don't give up on Bohemia. They've got quite a few obstacles to overcome in the beginning stages, what with the Hussite rebellion. Just take Jiri Z Podebrad and become emperor and then have your way with the world. Annexing Silesia on its own won't break you, but taking too much land too fast will.

While it is my hope that no one puts stock in the aggregated rating of a book on Goodreads, I know that people still do. So many of my favorite books are under 3.5 stars, because people use the rating system on their for personal use. Just recently, one of my friends rated Lincoln in the Bardo 2 stars because she was bothered by David Sedaris' voice in the audiobook. I get vehemently upset when people do this--and maybe I shouldn't--but I feel like if you're going to rate a book, you have to do so objectively. Goodreads simply isn't the place to look for impartial or informed ratings.
However, as a librarian, it is an immensely useful metric to use for recommendations, or finding popular books. Certainly, then, you'd want to follow reviews that have more reviews, but 1,000 ratings might be a little steep. Something with 3 reviews that all laud a book as the next To Kill a Mockingbird should be taken with a grain of salt, but a few hundred ratings that fluctuate between 1-5 stars is good enough for me.

The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle is my favorite so far by Murakami, probably due to its extreme focus on the introspective. It's historical underpinnings with Lieutenant Mamiya's story was fantastic, too. I hear some criticize it for meandering a bit, and Murakami is certainly notorious for not making his purpose clear, but I think all the dreamlike qualities and lucid prose in this one have some sort of underlying theme that was fun to pick apart.

**Shadowbahn, by Steve Erickson** and **At the Existentialist Cafe, by Sarah Bakewell**
Kinda of my first foray into experimental/speculative fiction with Shadowbahn, but it's deeply entrancing and a welcome reading challenge. Seeks to describe the state of the U.S., unnervingly prescient in its characterization of the nature of the nation. Erickson also employs music and its historical provenance with such remarkable precision.
At the Existentialist Cafe is a fun, well-chronicled account of existentialist philosophers; their lives, their ideologies, and the enveloping history that spawned the movement as well as the world that was subsequently informed by the movement. There's a passage about Franciscan priests and nuns doggedly working to subvert Nazi destruction of influential phenomenology manuscripts by smuggling them out of Prague. Having just recently read The Name of the Rose and A Canticle for Leibowitz, that part really stuck out as a poignant real-world preservation of knowledge situation.

I was going for Back to the Piast a few weeks ago and started as Silesia. Within 20 years or so I just happened to get a PU over Hungary, too. It was the easiest early games I've ever had the pleasure to experience. Ate Poland and become Poland in about 100 years.

I always like to talk about the intended themes that the author weaves into the narrative. Finding what the author has to say about their intentions for writing the work is usually informative, and helps frame some questions by connecting certain passages in the book to the overall themes. Looking up critical reviews for the book also helps to familiarize yourself with what other people notice. Bringing up points that reviewers mention to those in your club is always fun for sparking discussion.
For me, I like to prepare discussion questions if I'm leading the talk, so that I always have something to pivot back to if the discussion strays for too long. Note some things down that kind of stuck with you, or seem controversial, and ask for what people thought about those passages.
Another technique for me running healthy, friendly clubs is to feel the vibe of the group and try to challenge their assertions respectfully with some of the research you've acquired. Laugh along with points you might not necessarily agree with and then pose an alternative idea. Probably won't be too much of an issue to maintain a civil dialogue if you're doing it between friends, but just something to keep in mind, and helps to contribute fuller discussion.

As I commented on the other reply here, my problem isn't necessarily with not understanding how to produce an heir. I get the whole % heir chance. It's more trying to understand how to avoid getting a foreign dynasty to suddenly birth out an heir when marriage to a ruler of your desired dynasty. Is that prestige related?

The situation I just had was my Rurikovich queen, heirless, chose a prince consort from France from a typical royal marriage decision. In a couple years, a new heir was born. My Queen died and then her son, my heir, ascended, but to my horror, he was suddenly a de Valois.
So I didn't die heirless or accept any event. But I got into this unfortunate situation where I couldn't control which dynasty the heir chooses when he's born, and I got to thinking maybe I was forgetting something. Should I not ever offer a royal marriage without an heir, due to the risk of that nation's consort placing their dynasty on the throne? Or is this prestige related, where I should only be proposing royal marriages with nations lower than me until I have secured the desired dynasty?

WRITING.TITLE: Any tricks to retaining a dynasty indefinitely?
WRITING.TEXT:
Other than the mysterious chronic game crashes that so often plague us, are there any tips to keeping your dynasty's reign unbroken? This most directly affects something like the achievement Kinslayer, but I'd also be interested in this generally.
And can you know what dynasty your heir will be before they are born, based on the ruler and consort dynastic ties?

Thanks, friend.
Scotland and England were pretty upset, as well as the Irish minors. That was about it. If I took London in the first war, I definitely would've gotten some coalitions to form.

R5: Got the 4 provinces needed to core and culture convert as Denmark in 1471. Of course, it took quite a while longer to core and change to Danish culture. I ended up taking London and Ireland and getting PUs over the Palatinate and Brandenburg by the mid 1500s. Felt pretty good about this, for being an average filthy casual.
Edit: Forgot the relevant strategy, if you can call it that. All I had to do was watch France take back their provinces on the mainland, ally them, wait for England to hit the war of roses, declare no CB and ship my troops over to a perfectly ravaged Britain. Their navy was sitting in the English channel the entire time blockade English ports while their 10k troops hid in London while rebels were sieging down the Marches. France and Aragon helped, too.

WRITING.TITLE: Not super impressive, but proud of my 1471 conquering of the Danelaw region for the Iron Price achievement.

WRITING.TEXT:
Meissner Porcelain is really annoying. You basically need to inherit the Lowlands from Burgundy or else you won't have the time or trade income to colonize fast enough to reach all the Asian porcelain provinces. Then you need to prevent the Netherlands from spawning in your provinces (which I think consists of culture converting). Also, Ming doesn't seem to break up so often anymore, which makes it a bit harder since China has a lot of porcelain provinces you need.
Suffice to say, it hasn't been the most fun experience for me.
What have you done to Brandenburg?

It looks to me like you may have just taken land bordering their provinces. If you check your ally's diplomacy screen, you can hover over your relations to bring up a display that breaks down the specific negative modifiers in your relationship. Oftentimes, taking land near their own borders is encroaching on that nation's provinces of interest. You can check to see what each nation has marked as one of these PoI's in the diplomacy screen as well, in the tab for Trust/Favors.
You can see in this image below from the EU4 wiki the menu that should be selected. The mapmode should switch, showing the selected nation's provinces in green, provinces with claims in yellow, and provinces of interest in red. If you end up taking one of the provinces that they want, they'll probably end up becoming hostile. http://www.eu4wiki.com/images/thumb/1/11/Trust_and_Favors.png/800px-Trust_and_Favors.png
Otherwise, perhaps lend a little more context to your situation.

Luck of the Irish is like the feel good achievement for those of us who aren't super invested in trying some of EU4's hardest challenges. I did Thomond into Ireland and got super lucky take the Irish isle without England or Scotland claiming any part of the it first. I allied France and Scotland and used their combined might to take London in the first war against England. Then began about 100 years of warring England, spitting out Wales/Northumberland/Cornwall, taking way too much land form England and firing a coalition war of European powers, appeasing the coalition forces by forcing France to release some small nations, then getting dragged into wars as Spain smelled a weak France and ate up its southern border, then using France's remaining manpower to finish off the rest of England, watching Spain viciously pounce on the struggling French, then dropping all my alliances to turn to fighting off a remarkably advanced Scottish military to finally eke out a domination victory in the English isles by 1630. It was a whirlwind of emotions, but this achievement was hella fun.
End game mutilation of the French state: http://i.imgur.com/B9IovGL.jpg

Thanks. I took Edirne and then started another war with Serbia/Bosnia once the Ottomans foolishly warned me after losing the first war. Hungary fell into a PU with Austria, giving me a Balkans-hungry super ally to help.
During my war with the Ottomans/Serbia/Bosnia, and declared on Byzantium, took Constantinople, and made them my vassal. Adding to that, a chunk of Serbian/Bosnian and Ottoman lands. The only thing to fear now is the encroaching annihilation from thousands of different rebels!

WRITING.TITLE: What do I actually do when I win my first war as Albania vs. The Ottomans?
WRITING.TEXT:
So I've all but won my first war against the Ottomans as Albania, meaning that I've occupied all their land west of Constantinople. They targeted me first, so Byzantium is still alive and well.
I'm thinking of taking Edirne, to prevent the easy crossing from Anatolia, and whatever else warscore will allow. Is there something I should be plotting now to prepare for another conflict later? I assume the Ottomans will strike again once the treaty is up, and Skanderbeg might not be around during the next go of it. I guess the question is how to effectively neuter the Ottomans here while setting myself up for a successful Albania run. (I might try to do Albania or Iberia since I wouldn't really know what else to do if I became a strong Albania.)

You get it. I was going to use Civ-BE as an example of how the series needs its historical grounding or else the result is just lackluster, flavorless, tripe. But of course, this is merely one humble opinion.

As far as Economy goes, make sure to check the trade map and see all the centers of trade. Conquering those provinces which have higher trade value (specifically trade centers like Venice or Genoa, for example) will generate a lot money for you. Likewise, taking all the provinces within that trade node adds to the total income you get when placing a merchant there. However, controlling all the provinces in that trade node doesn't necessarily equate to boatloads of money, since a trade node like the White Sea in Russia isn't really all that valuable. You can check the value of each node in the trade menus. That's a down and dirty summary of trade. It's something to keep in the back of your mind when decided which provinces to take in wars. Taking a province in a trade node that you don't really have a lot of trade power in already, or don't have a merchant to really capitalize on there, it might not be financially beneficial for you to take. That's something I wish I knew a little earlier on, but I also started by playing mid-sized nations like Bohemia and Florence, so it's not so detrimental of a folly if you're playing the likes of Russia or France.
Manpower and army management I've always struggled with, too. Recently I've become more aware of minimizing my losses in wars by manipulating my allies to fight as many battles for me so I don't have to lose out. Letting your allies take the brunt of the casualties takes patience, but it allows you to keep your manpower higher. Also what people have been saying about infantry mercenaries being super useful and cost efficient is true.
Province improvements--and I may be wrong here--seem like just a way for the rich to get richer. It's hard to justify building churches in my provinces across Bohemia if I can only generate the 200 ducats needed to build one every 5 years. It's definitely better to build improvements early on to reap more, but if you don't have the money to spend, don't spend it. Only build a market in provinces that are centers of trade in a trade node you collect from, for example. Otherwise you're just bankrupting yourself for a profit you won't even see for 50 years.
Alliances seem to be best made with nations that are not close to you. Using Bohemia again as an example, allying France is great if your intention is to take out much of the HRE nations, and even better if you're looking to expand east. For France, ally Castile/Spain if you don't care about the Iberian peninsula and want to mess up mainland Europe. In my experience, usually you shouldn't be too worried about your alliances restricting your expansion. You can always break alliances if they become a hindrance. Although, I have come across instances where playing as a newly formed Italy, France, The Ottomans, and Super Sweden become the wonder friends and completely block any expansion whatsoever. In those situations, it was usually a deference on my part throughout the course of the game in trying to limit any one of these three great powers. You have to try and predict who might be an issue later in the game (typically, France's military bonuses always set them up to be a powerful foe by the end, whereas the PLC/Russia/Ottomans start to fall behind on military effectiveness), and then plan around that. Understand the nation you're playing and know how strong surrounding nations are liable to become. Danish ideas are trash for military-focused runs, whereas Prussia is one of the most obvious, strong military nations. Therefore, if playing as Denmark, wipe out Brandenburg's potential to harm you later in the early game and ally yourself with France and hope you remain good friends!
These are just a few things I've grappled with, so hopefully some of it helps. There's simply way too much to try and explain, and I certainly don't have the mastery of this game to be the one to hit the more complex strategies that some of the ablest EU4 players employ. Definitely check out streamers or youtube channels of famous players like Arrumba or DDRJake or whoever else was mentioned. Good luck in your future campaigns!

Going off on a bit of a tangent, here, but your comment about how one can easily replace Civ's leaders with fantasy cultures is exactly what the game Endless Legend sets out to do. It's like this hidden gem of the 4X, turn-based strategy genre that does everything Civ does but better. Plug over.
Civilization leans on history so much with familiar faces and cultural constructs--those "recognizable symbols of history" as mentioned in the article. It's a novel idea (Whoa ho! Ghandi is building the Pyramids, and amassing a giant army to wipe out the Aztecs!) that is just kind of stretched thin. It's disappointing that Civilization has this media monopoly on 4X games, and other more compelling and innovative games often go unheard of.
However, while EU4 is certainly vastly different, comparing them doesn't seem so sacrilegious to me. The author of the article is aware that they are different genres, and is simply comparing them on how each approach historical content. In a way, he's actually contrasting the two games, even if he thinks he's striking a comparison (he says they each "highlight two starkly different approaches to historical source material"), since the bulk of the article is exposing the differences between the games.
I mean, honestly, the outcome of this article only serves to bolster more exposure of EU4, simply because it is being "compared" to such a big name in video games. If his intention is to be biased toward EU4, he chose the right demographic to appeal to. What other high-profile PC game audience would even be minutely interested in a grand strategy game like EU4? Overwatch/League fans? Counterstrike or CoD players? The people that are going to read this article are mainly those curious as to why their much-loved game--Civilization--is being lumped together with something called EU4.
So mainly, exposing EU4 to the Civ community will pay more dividends then most other loyal fanbases of other genres, and the author's intent to "compare" these two games in the same genre (despite the article solely contrasting two different approaches) could just be his way of facetiously bridging together like-minded demographics. In any case, I say the more Civ -- EU4 converts the better!

And as a related question, is the only mechanic for embracing institutions to purchase them once you reaching that 10% spread? Other than wait for it to spread through all provinces, of course.
Because for nations like England, getting the Renaissance early in London is fairly quick and painless, but then you have all the land north of you is struggling to catch up. I don't want to wait for the spread, because that puts me behind, but dropping hundreds of ducats seems like a steep price, too.

Oh my god, I never thought how much I wanted the ability to depose popes and create antipopes until now. I've been reading the Name of the Rose, and that all about the feud between the Pope at Avignon and Louis IV, where the latter set up his own antipope in Rome after conquering through Italy.
I think currently the Curia is pretty lame, and controlling it doesn't give much substantial bonus. Calling for crusades are cool I guess, and excommunicating helps me take lands from rulers around me, but I feel like there could be more depth in this field. Hopefully they make an expansion in the future around this area of the game.

1. I'd say yes, but with two caveats: 1) You need to be the war leader to ensure you get what you want from the Teutonic Order, and 2) expect to backstab/break the alliance soon after robbing the Poles of their provinces.
2. If you can, go for it. You can also see if allying Austria is feasible and coast along on the Emperor's good graces. It probably also depends on what you're planning on doing with Brandenburg, but I wouldn't put a ton of resources into weaseling your way into becoming the emperor until you get a solid foundation. Brandenburg does not have much power at the start, so strengthening your position should be your first goal.
3. A lot of the time, Lubeck or Hamburg allies Riga, so I'd look to declare on them to take those free cities. You might be able to coax Poland into a war against the Livonian Order, set Riga as a co-belligerent, and steal Lubeck/Hamburg that way. In short, declare on their allies, or directly on them when the emperor is busy.
Greece!
A rebel controlled city is not taken into that 87% warscore, so maybe Sweden is holding out until they can siege it down for themselves.
Is your colonist currently occupied somewhere else?

I think Bohemia is pretty fun, and since they are landlocked, you don't necessarily have to worry about trading or colonizing if you don't want to. (Although I rushed to the Pomeranian coastline in one game ((HRE AE BE DAMNED)) and was able to start up Bohemian Colombia and control the Panama canal. Great fun).
It is a pretty good alternative introduction to HRE mechanics, too, as you're a fairly strong nation that's not the typical powerhouses Austria or Brandenburg, and it has flexibility in the route you wish to take. In other words, because Bohemia doesn't really have an obvious track to take like Austria's diplomacy game or Brandenburg becoming Space Marines, the world is your oyster. The only downside to that is that aren't really any Bohemian specific events apart from the Hussite stuff in the beginning of the game to add flavor to the run.
For flavor, the other post about Poland is a great idea, too. You don't have to worry about colonizing and trade too much with them either, but they become a lot to control if you're not used to managing PUs with large countries, and then immediately half x2 troops after incorporating them and becoming an empire. My first successful Commonwealth game was a little jarring when I went from casually declaring wars and letting Lithuanian AI do everything for me to actually have to manage all the giant stacks of military myself. Maybe I'm just a lazy war leader.
Forming Italy is pretty fun, too, and you really only have to worry about placing merchants in Genoa or Venice in regard to trade. Florence-Tuscany-Italy was easy enough and rewarding back when I did it.
TLDR; Bohemia for an alternative introduction to HRE play, Poland for more flavor and more overt power, or an Italian minor like Florence and form Italy and never worry about money again.

Can confirm, am American and it took me a few seconds.
Because Month/Day/Year is the most logically hierarchical structure to express dates.

I can't see how your tech situation is coming along, but if you're on par or leading in military tech, you can definitely take the coast along the Levant all the way up Africa to the Spanish in a short amount of time. If you don't got anything better to do, go for it and let us know how it turns out!

Like everyone has been saying, I agree with the Ottoman alliance recommendation. Denmark usually is never able to hold Sweden on its own, and has pretty bad military ideas. You say you don't mind helping them contain the Swedes, but I think it's a significant drain on your forces if you commit to that. In addition, a lot of the time the Scandinavians end up with missions to take Osel, or other Baltic states, or simply set them to high priority, so they wouldn't ally with you for long. I'd just let them go at each others throats for a while and clean up the region for yourself between Russian conquests. As Poland, grabbing as much of the Baltic Sea node is important.
The Ottomans typically end up bordering Russia once both nations expand into the Caucasus, and will certainly be an able and willing ally for your wars. Plus, you should be able to backstab them and outpower their military eventually with your godlike cavalry bonuses. You know, cuz, remove Kebab and all that.

I give this playthrough a B+, with an extra bonus of Swedish USA and the most passive rival giant France this world has ever seen.

WRITING.TITLE: Running a Book Club Discussion on The Name of the Rose, Need Help!
WRITING.TEXT:
Hey everyone, I'm going to be heading a discussion for my library's book club on The Name of the Rose, by Umberto Eco. I think my group will like the the underlying murder mystery story, but will certainly be confused by heavy mention of the feud going on between the pope, the emperor, and the various monastic orders and their branch sects. Hell, even I'm a little lost, finding myself re-reading sections to get a firm grip on the situation.
I would like to be able to provide a primer of sorts for the group, the month before they begin reading, to prepare them for what's important and try and clarify some of the history before they go in blindly. I'd look online, but as I haven't actually finished the book myself yet, I didn't want to spoil the plot. Basically, I'm asking for those of you who have read the book to provide the most essential bits of this whole historical context, in the frame of not ruining any part of the actual plotline, so that I can give my group a quick lesson on what's important for them to know to give them a fuller understanding the story. For example, I know I'll need to explain the relationship between the Franciscan/Benedictine orders as I'm sensing the significance it will have on the conflicting ideologies of William and the other monks.
As much as I would love to do a comprehensive history lesson, teaching my group about the complexities of 14th century secular vs. religious powers in Europe, it'll simply be too much. They typically only want to read CJ Box stories, so this whole literary historical murder mystery is a bit ambitious.

I don't really know how I can fight France at this point, and I probably won't even try. Their rise to power is on me, and I must suffer the consequences. Luckily, they won't rival me and don't seem to be inclined to go to war with me. Maybe we can just coexist ( )

I think it's possible, but you'll be cutting it close. Hopefully someone who's done the MN run themselves can weigh, because I'm not a particularly advanced player either.
What you've got going for you is a huge army. England seems to be pretty weakened, so taking London won't be difficult. If you can take all of Italy by 1600 and then spend the next 200 years or so grabbing all that coast line, it seems possible.
What seems worrisome is that your aggressive expansion has pissed off a lot of people. The trick is going to be how well you can manipulate alliances, manage AE, and deter any kind of a meaningful coalitions from forming.
In regard to Kebab, they'll lose their potency later in the game. If you can ally PLC or Russia or even a strong Sweden/Scandanavia, you should be able to take what you need from them. I would think Kebab will be your final boss for the game.
Make sure you're grabbing those other weird provinces like Zeeland and Vienna and whatever else the Roman Empire requires. If you go for it, share some pictures of the process! Good luck, sir.

Sometimes Poland rivals you, but then maybe Austria can help. Allying the HRE usually lets you conquer provinces within the empire more easily then. If they rival you, too, then I don't know man, look for France or something. Brandenburg isn't the easiest start.

I think they've tried balancing the game more so you can't straight up declare war without consideration now. With Sweden I know the best strategy is to building up a fleet really fast and trap the Danes once they send their entire army to take back Gottland. I haven't tried in myself, but it sounds like it would effectively cut off all land units in your independence war so long as your navy holds the blockage.
Brandenburg also isn't easy in the beginning; their provinces suck. You need to utilize alliances more in the early game to get you into a good spot. Poland is a pretty easy alliance to secure with them, since you both have a common enemy in the Teutonic Order.
Easiest nations I think are the Ottomans and probably Muscovy. You can do almost anything you want to the small nations around you with little penalty. Ottomans are more forgiving, but Muscovy is fairly braindead, too.

I don't quite know the answer to all of these, but here's what I got:
2.) A lot of things go into how a battle is decided. The composition of your army factors in, so pretty much make sure your infantry/cavalry/artillery numbers are proportioned appropriately (I don't have specifics, but EU4 tells you not to have more than half your infantry in cavalry. I see a ton of people with like 10-12 infantry and 3-4 cavalry, which works out well in many cases).
Military tech discrepancy plays a huge role in battles, too. If you're behind 1 tech, they're going to be much more effective. Obviously, if you're lagging behind 2-3+ you'll be pretty useless.
Military generals also have an impact, and they have a simple ranking system of 1, 2, or 3 stars, with each rank being (generally speaking) significantly better. Each general has individual blips that indicate his strength in one of four categories (Fire, charge, maneuver, and siege) which give a more detailed view of why a general is ranked 1, 2, or 3 stars. If you don't have a general leading an army fighting against an army that does, that's bad news.
Finally, terrain and defensive bonuses have the potential to really wreck your morale and fighting power. If you're Venice moving into Savoy, odds are you're getting negative modifiers for crossing into mountains or over rivers. Northern Italy is a mountainous region and is a pain to fight offensively in (from my experience). You want to try and maneuver around so that you avoid being the one on the offensive. You can tell if you'll get a crossing penalty when you pause and click to move your army to the target army. It should show a red minus sign where the battle is to take place.
Considering you're losing 33k to 11k, odds are you are experiencing more than one of these potentially harmful effects.
4.) If I'm reading this correctly, the country you want to gain trust with is a rival, and therefore, it's pretty much impossible to do so. Rivals are designed to dislike you until the AI decides you aren't a rival anymore. Honestly, I'm not sure the specifics pertaining to when AI feels like unrival-ing, but it probably has part to do with provinces of strategic importance and size of nation. If that country has claims on you, they want your land and probably won't rest until they get them or die trying.
5.) The only way I know of is you can enforce peace with the target of your ally, only if your ally has +100 relations. Most times the computer only accepts when they're losing, so it kind of defeats the purpose of the diplomatic action in my eyes.
I, for one, appreciate your lil' boot, and have never had Iberia and Great Britain and also the Maghreb and Jerusalem by that time.

I've been doing another run before listening to any feedback and I've vassal-annexing Teutonic order and Holstein, and have vacillated between taking coastal HRE states alongside wars with Novgorod, Lvonian Order, and the Teutons. This has allowed me to pay off 2 coalitions that spawned (including probably 70% of HRE states) with 500+gold and East Frisia, or 500+gold and Stettin.
It's 1500 now and liberty desire is under check for now (I rejected the Scandinavian Constitution like you said), I'm finally back down to acceptable levels of AE after 2 massive coalition wars took next to nothing meaningful, and Muscovy lost Moskva to the Golden Horde so now I'm just patiently eating them up and recovering cores for my vassalized Novgobear.
I'm definitely going to look into getting Prussian ideas, as Poland actually took Danzig in its first war and are my only tangible rivals. Luckily they chose to not grab the PU with Lithuania. Barring I don't fuck it all up, this could be a decent run for the Danes.

Interesting idea for releasing Novgorod after they are eaten up. I went for an immediate vassalization of them after Muscovy's first war, but then they rose up with Sweden for independence shortly thereafter.

WRITING.TITLE: Alright, How Do I Succeed with Denmark?
WRITING.TEXT:
So I've been trying to play Denmark recently and maybe I'm just horrible at managing PUs, but I can't for the life of me figure out what the best start would be.
First, the beginning mission of "Danish Trade" (securing Danzig, Lubeck, and Neva) just seems completely unreasonable to do within any reasonable time frame. If I go for Novgorod, Muscovy rivals me. If I take Danzig, Poland hates me. If I somehow manage to take Lubeck, the entire HRE get upset. Should I just never take this mission, or do I need to employ some god-like level of patience in completing it? Pissing off three major powers around me while juggling with the liberty desire of Sweden is insane.
And on the topic of Sweden, the minute any powerful nation rivals me, they tend to support Sweden's independence and the encroaching opportunistic war with Sweden bars me from trying to make any expansions. I've come to conclude that trying to keep Sweden under a PU is close to impossible, and I shouldn't bother trying to integrate them, so what's the best course of action regarding them?
Pretty much I integrate Holstein and Norway as soon as possible, and I can usually take quite a few Baltic Sea border territories by 1500 (Some of Novgorod, a lot of either the Lvonian or Teutonic Order, and sometimes a bit of Pomerania), but as I said before, usually Sweden or Muscovy or PLC decide it's time to reverse my advances. I have no idea how to create a strong start without it immediately crumbling and losing cores back to Sweden.

I'm fairly certain the coalition won't trigger if you accept a call to arms and enter on behalf of an entirely separate war.
Though, that's not to say the coalition members won't declare on you while you're fighting that war. You'll be treading a fine line there, but if they don't declare and you don't take any land in that war, you'll at least prevent Florence from any future coalition war for as long as you have a truce with them.

Never let them blob. NEVER LET THEM BLOB.
Otherwise, the most effective strategy for a shit player like me is to wait it out. They tend to lag behind in tech eventually and become nearly as useless as Russia's millions of troops.

What I've learned is to drop allies before they start to bring you down. If you don't see Muscovy being able to fight back and put the PLC in check, then back out of the alliance. If you're strong enough to take on the PLC, though, either with Russia later or with other allies now, they could be a good target for you. The Baltic states would be great land to boost your trade in the Baltic node (ie. take the entire coast line away from whoever owns it.)
Really, it's usually not simply "Who should I fight," but "How can I manipulate alliances to get me the land I want." If you're dropping Muscovy, try to find someone to take their place. If you want to keep them, understand they might try to call you into a war with the PLC in the future.

In regard to fabricating claims now, the difference is simply having to send a diplomat to establish a spy network and waiting for enough points to fabricate. It takes a few months, but once you get to 20+ points in the network, the "Fabricate Claim" option should be lit up in the Covert Actions tabs. Those 20 points then get consumed for the claim and viola! Back to your old conquering ways.
The only caveat is the cost to fabricate goes up for every action claim you have on a nation (20, 25, 30, and so on). I guess what also changed since the last time you played might be the default casus belli being humiliation wars if you're declaring on a rival. If you're not used to reading what casus belli you're using when you declare, now's the time to make sure you're not starting a humiliation war--these wars do NOT allow you to take provinces. (Humiliation wars are available for rival nations, almost as soon as you set them as such)

I don't remember the last time Russia has ever helped me enough to justifying them taking up a diplomatic relationship slot. They are constantly plagued by whoever ends up gaining the upper hand in the region (Ottomans, or PLC, or Sweden, or even a horde). They have a lot of troops, but they're still a little garbage can.

People always have recommended watching videos by Arumba or DDRJake. I've found them to be pretty useful, regardless of whether the nation they are playing is something I'd want to ever try. They know mechanics really well. They also keep up with the expansions.
Ayyy but they're beating back the highlanders! +1 warscore baby we're on fire!

Not to my knowledge. As long as you pull a white peace or more they remain your lesser partner. Make sure to check the treaty terms, it should say something along the lines of "Bohemia will remain in a PU." You don't need a special treaty.
Bohemia. They're like the little Elector that could. No advantages and typically surrounded by enemies all game long.

We don't need to analyze it unless people are trying to gauge the character of Dardoch. Looking at the way he presents himself during the interview: his posture (crossing his arms is typically a sign of defensiveness, and unwillingness to engage in constructive conversation) and the way he begins twitching into a smile when the crowd cheers him on shows an incredibly emotionally immature individual. He's letting his emotions guide his opinions, not the facts regarding how his team performed.
It's this kind of attitude that gets people riled up, and the same reason why when DL trash-talks people, others don't get as upset. Dardoch is unstable and lets emotions dictate his opinions, whereas typical trash-talk is more benign banter and innocuous bravado. It's pretty apparent why he got suspended at the start of the season with this worrying, childish blame-game display here. He doesn't take full responsibility on what is objectively his team's fault for losing that game.
That being said, he's a teenager. He's so unique and divisive because he "speaks his mind," and I suppose that's why people think he's so edgy and great. But at the core of it he's a teenager who doesn't know how to appropriately deal with defeat. He won't develop positively as a player if he points to the reason of defeat on one teamfight, because that's the state of the game right now. "They're not the better team, not even close" is a statement someone oblivious, delusional, or simply emotionally heated would make, because while TL could be the better team, asserting that CLG is "not even close" is simply incorrect given they've beaten them in 2 series now. If he can't understand how to play the game all the way through to a win, then of course he'll lose and never get better. If he can't acknowledge that his team is much more close in skill level than the rest of the competition, then again, he'll continue to lose. It's kind of a part of growing up, accepting that you're not some invincible, special, unique little butterfly that deserves to win all the time.
TL;DR For all the people defending him, saying he's merely showing confidence, they're wrong. He is clearly tilted based on his mannerisms and tone. He is, in fact, very tilted, and falls back on his usual display of defensiveness and brazen arrogance.
Who honestly cares whether this is trashtalk? It's his punk-ass busta mindset that should be a worrying trend for TL fans.
But I understand your disappointment.

Actually, I released Croatia and Venice to get out of a war with Poland and friends while conquering Brandenburg. Croatia then took over all of Venice and the subsequently lost all of their land to an Ottoman invasion. Poor Croats.
The first time I've ever expanded throughout the HRE without a care in the world about how much AE I was accumulating. Oh, it felt so good to finally be so (moderately) successful.

WRITING.TITLE: Austria-Hungarian Germany

WRITING.TEXT: I want my crushing to MEAN something, my friend.

Around 1720 I had the chance to contest Poland when they claimed a PU over France and thoroughly destroy 2/3 of my only enemies in the game. But I accidentally skipped over the notification when I clicked ESC. Since it was an RNG event, I couldn't even go back to a previously backup save. It was the worst moment of my life, hands down.
I'll keep the dream alive, though. No one plays this game for fun. We play to remove kebab/baguette.

Good thinking, I'll look into those. Thanks! I've already formed Italy before, and I think I've got the City of Cities. Dismantling the HRE means France/Polish/Ottoman alliance will take me out rather quickly, I feel, but hey, whatever. Austria has had its time.

I'm Austria, noble duchy and member of the HRE. (I lost my emperor status and converted to reformed for fun.) I'm allied with Spain, Portugal, Brandenburg, Sweden, and Lithuania. Naples is my march and Bavaria is my highly rebellious vassal, with the Ottomans supporting their independence.
I'm fairly certain I can win whatever war I choose next, but I'm running out of time and would like to make it worth my time. Not sure if there's anything cool I could do, cuz I usually never get this strong. Maybe I'll reconvert to catholicism and try and for Germany or something. I don't know, really.
Any ideas, guys?

WRITING.TITLE: Anybody have suggestions on what achievements I can do?

WRITING.TEXT: Great, but what have you done to the Podebrads? Zerotin is a filthy Hapsburg puppet.

I took photos chronicling the progression of a completely AI dictated Europe over the miserable years plodding around Arabia and Persia. Castile and Aragon get special recognition for going at each others throats for 200+ years. http://imgur.com/a/YoVMB
Anyway, just thought I'd share my accomplishment. I don't care that the EU4 Wiki says its a medium difficulty achievement, I got it in a single go having never played a non-European country before, and it's 3:30am and I'm tired and need to sleep. I hope Freddy is proud of me.

WRITING.TITLE: only took 368 years to achieve Queen of Mercury AND I got the pleasure of witnessing the AI partition France.

WRITING.TEXT:
I don't know how man, I just broke an alliance with the UK when France declared war on them. Then Russian Louisiana started their own war with a French colony and I spent 10k gold to get out of it.
Bohemia is emperor and allied to them, France has a third of the US and all of Iberia and what Aragon colonized. The Ottomans are my rival. There are no other super powers worth a damn.
Someone help.

France, the only rival I could select besides the Ottomans, apparently integrated Aragon. Didn't even realizing they have a PU.
Not like this...

WRITING.TITLE: Suddenly, A Wild FrAragon Appears

WRITING.TEXT: But how is Novgobear faring?

Yeah, something happened when I converted to Protestantism that demoted me to Duchy a long while into the campaign. I thought it was kind of funny, then forgot by the end that I'd never upgraded back up. Thus, the Duchy of Bohemia was born.
EDIT: I actually just read somewhere that becoming Emperor might have had something to do with it. Especially cuz I then lost emperorship and also my elector status thereafter. Due to the whole being Protestant thing.

WRITING.TITLE: The Great and Glorious Duchy of Bohemia, Purveyor of Pilsner and Justice, an AAR: Part 2, Young Holland and the Big, Bad Commonwhore Offensive

WRITING.TEXT:
;D
Every few years, Cornwall separatists bounced up to 80-90%. Not even the English rebels cared as much about their independence as you tenacious lads. The name calling was a sign of begrudging respect, I assure you.

While I feel slightly bad, in other playthroughs for this achievement, France would either refuse to cross the channel when they went to war with England, or they would go too far and claim every single province they took. It was a bittersweet turn of events for me.

Haven't decided, I'm only just now getting a respectable income. I don't really have any powerful allies anymore, because I expended nearly all of them on my conquest of the isles. I'll have to set a new achievement goal and work for that, though I'm not sure what that might be yet.
Or if you just want to see my Europe upon completion of the achievement: http://i.imgur.com/8RVzVzr.jpg

WRITING.TITLE: What's the craic, Great Britain? A Fabulous, Meticulous, Masterfully Played Photo Adventure of the "Luck of the Irish"

WRITING.TEXT: I think it may have had something to do with an event that forced the country Protestant or a female heir become Queen. Some point around then I lost half my alliances and my elector status and I didn't really understand what happened. I just assumed was a duchy all game, which in hindsight, yes, makes absolutely no sense.
I'm 50% Bohemian, 100% dirty American. I like my history and dogs and potato based products.
Even the great and glorious mother Bohemia makes typos.
http://i.imgur.com/ExvjgTM.jpg Spoiler alert, Bohemia ended the game as a Duchy.

WRITING.TITLE: The Great and Glorious Duchy of Bohemia, Purveyor of Pilsner and Justice, an AARP: Part 1, In Search of Dogs

WRITING.TEXT: From my experience here, yeah, Italian countries look really fun. Florence was great because of how much money I was making at basically all points in my run. Even though I couldn't ever match the might of most big nation armies, I could sure as hell triple my standing army in mercenaries in every war. It you want more of a challenge, though, it might be worthwhile trying some other Italian minor. I've only got like 200hrs logged, so what do I know?

I think it just happened to be in range, since it was a coastal province and I had already cored Granada and then Asturias (the strange out-of-place green province in northern Castile you might see lingering in one of the images of my post-war spoils from France).
